lines.text: Enter ORLANDO and OLIVER

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Is't possible that on so little acquaintance you should like her? that but seeing you should love her? and loving woo? and, wooing, she should grant? and will you persever to enjoy her?

lines.speaker: oliver
lines.text: Neither call the giddiness of it in question, the poverty of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden wooing, nor her sudden consenting; but say with me, I love Aliena; say with her that she loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other: it shall be to your good; for my father's house and all the revenue that was old Sir Rowland's will I estate upon you, and here live and die a shepherd.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: You have my consent. Let your wedding be to-morrow: thither will I invite the duke and all's contented followers. Go you and prepare Aliena; for look you, here comes my Rosalind.
Enter ROSALIND

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: God save you, brother.

lines.speaker: oliver
lines.text: And you, fair sister.
Exit

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: O, my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear thy heart in a scarf!

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: It is my arm.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to swoon when he showed me your handkerchief?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Ay, and greater wonders than that.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: O, I know where you are: nay, 'tis true: there was never any thing so sudden but the fight of two rams and Caesar's thrasonical brag of 'I came, saw, and overcame:' for your brother and my sister no sooner met but they looked, no sooner looked but they loved, no sooner loved but they sighed, no sooner sighed but they asked one another the reason, no sooner knew the reason but they sought the remedy; and in these degrees have they made a pair of stairs to marriage which they will climb incontinent, or else be incontinent before marriage: they are in the very wrath of love and they will together; clubs cannot part them.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: They shall be married to-morrow, and I will bid the duke to the nuptial. But, O, how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man's eyes! By so much the more shall I to-morrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Why then, to-morrow I cannot serve your turn for Rosalind?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I can live no longer by thinking.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking. Know of me then, for now I speak to some purpose, that I know you are a gentleman of good conceit: I speak not this that you should bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are; neither do I labour for a greater esteem than may in some little measure draw a belief from you, to do yourself good and not to grace me. Believe then, if you please, that I can do strange things: I have, since I was three year old, conversed with a magician, most profound in his art and yet not damnable. If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries it out, when your brother marries Aliena, shall you marry her: I know into what straits of fortune she is driven; and it is not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow human as she is and without any danger.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Speakest thou in sober meanings?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, though I say I am a magician. Therefore, put you in your best array: bid your friends; for if you will be married to-morrow, you shall, and to Rosalind, if you will. Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.
Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE

lines.speaker: phebe
lines.text: Youth, you have done me much ungentleness, To show the letter that I writ to you.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I care not if I have: it is my study To seem despiteful and ungentle to you: You are there followed by a faithful shepherd; Look upon him, love him; he worships you.

lines.speaker: phebe
lines.text: Good shepherd, tell this youth what 'tis to love.

lines.speaker: silvius
lines.text: It is to be all made of sighs and tears; And so am I for Phebe.

lines.speaker: phebe
lines.text: And I for Ganymede.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: And I for Rosalind.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: And I for no woman.

lines.speaker: silvius
lines.text: It is to be all made of faith and service; And so am I for Phebe.

lines.speaker: phebe
lines.text: And I for Ganymede.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: And I for Rosalind.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: And I for no woman.

lines.speaker: silvius
lines.text: It is to be all made of fantasy, All made of passion and all made of wishes, All adoration, duty, and observance, All humbleness, all patience and impatience, All purity, all trial, all observance; And so am I for Phebe.

lines.speaker: phebe
lines.text: And so am I for Ganymede.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: And so am I for Rosalind.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: And so am I for no woman.

lines.speaker: phebe
lines.text: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

lines.speaker: silvius
lines.text: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Who do you speak to, 'Why blame you me to love you?'

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Pray you, no more of this; 'tis like the howling of Irish wolves against the moon. I will help you, if I can: I would love you, if I could. To-morrow meet me all together. I will marry you, if ever I marry woman, and I'll be married to-morrow: I will satisfy you, if ever I satisfied man, and you shall be married to-morrow: I will content you, if what pleases you contents you, and you shall be married to-morrow. As you love Rosalind, meet: as you love Phebe, meet: and as I love no woman, I'll meet. So fare you well: I have left you commands.
To SILVIUS
To PHEBE
To PHEBE
To ORLANDO
To SILVIUS
To ORLANDO
To SILVIUS

lines.speaker: silvius
lines.text: I'll not fail, if I live.

lines.speaker: phebe
lines.text: Nor I.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Nor I.
Exeunt
